nytimes_articles.headline: Rose Goes From Charlie Hustle to Charlie Horsepower
nytimes_articles.abstract: There is a new Pete Rose now -- still the same old Charlie Hustle from his 24 years of remarkable play for three major league teams, but different. The 52-year-old Rose has exchanged the baseball cap and jersey for a white fireproof jumpsuit, an orange helmet and a bulging life vest. And instead of running the bases, he is driving a monster of an offshore powerboat, a red 40-footer that will take him to speeds approaching 120 miles an hour.   The 2,200-horsepower boat, Hit King, is one of many new diversions in the life of a man who rewrote the record books with 4,256 career hits. Rose's gambling led to his banishment from baseball in 1989. And in 1990, his failure to file proper income tax returns sent him to prison for five months. The abrupt and brutal end of an extraordinary career sent him searching for other competitive outlets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Music; Anthrax Brings the Noise, but Now With Melody
nytimes_articles.abstract: "What do you think of the new guy?" the guitarist Scott Ian asked fans when Anthrax performed at the Grand on May 24. The new guy was John Bush, Anthrax's new lead vocalist, who also co-wrote the songs on the band's new album, "Sound of White Noise" (Elektra). To break him in, Anthrax was finishing up a six-date club tour before returning to its usual arena circuit.   With Mr. Bush, Anthrax's music shifts just slightly from the speed-metal that has sold millions of Anthrax albums since the mid-1980's. The band used to touch on slow heavy-metal riffing on the way to doubletime speed-metal blitzes with fast, one-note chanted lyrics. Now the slow passages are longer, and there's often a melody within the crashing, churning, pounding guitars and drums. The transformation of Anthrax isn't as drastic as Metallica's was, but both have decided to use just enough outside elements to break free of the speed-metal genre and crash the rock mainstream.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Watching "Movements for Piano and Orchestra" is like watching bolts of lightning. But because this lightning is choreographed by George Balanchine, everything is always under control, and the electrical storm is awesome without also being threatening.    Gestures are jagged and patterns are restless throughout the work, which was offered by the New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater as part of the Balanchine Celebration. Balanchine obviously listened closely to the Stravinsky score that serves as the ballet's title. What he heard inspired him in several ways. The choreography's nervous energy is obviously a response to that of the music. Yet the score never grows hysterical; Stravinsky created an ultimately orderly wildness. So did Balanchine.

nytimes_articles.headline: Big City Budget Reality

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Concert; Chamber Ensemble Vs. Noise: Music Wins
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's getting to be the time of year when music goes outdoors to play. Tanglewood, Caramoor and the like are yet to begin, but in the middle of Manhattan the concert and performance series at Bryant Park has acted as a kind of spring harbinger for the summer. The latest in these brief al fresco events was a collection of three short comic operas put on by the New York Chamber Ensemble for a few hundred sun-drenched listeners and passersby on Saturday afternoon. The pieces were Hindemith's "Hin und Zuruck"; "The Telephone" by Gian Carlo Menotti, and Douglas Moore's soap-opera opera, "Gallantry."   Previous events in Bryant Park, at least the ones this writer has attended, have faced some pretty stiff competition from traffic along the Avenue of the Americas and on 42d Street. But whether it was the weekend slowdown or the placing of the small stage at the east rather than the west end of the park, music held its own against city noise more effectively than I can remember it ever doing so.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mysteriously, Arson Takes Its Toll on New Hampshire's Treasured Covered Bridges
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Someone is burning the treasured covered bridges of New Hampshire. Cavernous and creaky, with their barnlike roofs and their sides latticed like pie crust, the covered bridges have stood guard over many of the Granite State's creeks and rivers for more than a century.

The bridges have survived floods and storms, and the ceaseless passing of time, but in a rash of recent arson fires three of the bridges have been destroyed since March, in three towns within 100 miles of one another. The most recent fire targeted a 157-year-old piece of history called Corbin Bridge, which went down in flames early Tuesday morning in the town of Newport. One woman told the local newspaper she had cried at the news.

The family in the show at the Union Square Theater is related to Charlie Chaplin, and the picture of the Little Tramp at the circus gives the amiable vest-pocket entertainment its sustaining imagery. nytimes_articles.headline: The War in Pictures
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Censorship decisions made some 50 years ago still affect Americans' memories of World War II. U.S. censorship, although less restrictive than that of other combatants, kept tens of thousands of photographs hidden. In researching my book "The Censored War: American Visual Experience During World War II" (to be published this summer by Yale University Press), I examined the National Archives' holdings of these photographs, which were not released by censors until the 1980's. Four are reproduced here.

Many of the images were graphic depictions of death that one would expect to find in a file that Army censors' memos called the "Chamber of Horrors." But the file also held photographs of such seemingly innocuous activities as officers fishing, G.I.'s partying and black men socializing with white women.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Jane Jacobs is lost in Toronto. Among the world's pre-eminent "foot people," as she termed urbanites like herself in "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," she is riding in the passenger seat of a car, looking uncharacteristically puzzled.   More than three decades have passed since Mrs. Jacobs, now 77, wrote "The Death and Life of Great American Cities." Many books are hyped as "seminal." nytimes_articles.headline: Bronx School Struggles Despite Praise and Fame
nytimes_articles.abstract: Everywhere, the children make music. They stroke the keys in the piano room and they caress violins in the auditorium. They sing in the musty, peeling theater built in 1914 where, just outside the door, beleaguered men gather along Boston Road and dogs sleep on the sidewalk.   St. Augustine School of the Arts, a nationally renowned Roman Catholic elementary school in the South Bronx, is experiencing the best and worst of times. An award-winning documentary about the school opened in New York on Friday, and the school's principal was recently honored as one of the nation's outstanding educators. But a fire last December that destroyed two-thirds of the main school building has left St. Augustine struggling to maintain its financial footing.

nytimes_articles.abstract: In a veterans hospital, the wars sometimes never end, and memories are carried deep in lasting wounds and lost years. nytimes_articles.abstract: With new vote totals showing a neck-and-neck race between Cambodia's ruling party and the royalist opposition founded by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Government protested to the United Nations today what it said were "irregularities" in last week's elections. nytimes_articles.abstract: Concerned by critical backlogs in appeals court cases coming from most of New York City and its suburbs, Gov. Mario M. The warning was issued Friday. The problem was first brought to light by an engineer at Northeast Utilities in Connecticut, who said later that he had been harassed for raising safety questions. She wore a red sari with gold trim that her uncle had brought from Bombay. He wore a bejeweled turban and a black suit. nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Running the Full Gamut Of Balanchine's Ballet
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Liebeslieder Walzer," which the New York City Ballet will perform tonight at the New York State Theater, and "Raymonda Variations," which is scheduled for Friday, symbolize the two poles of the company's continuing "Balanchine Celebration."   "Raymonda Variations" (1961) is typical of George Balanchine's work -- a plotless suite of solos and ensembles in which he reiterates his allegiance to ballet's 350-year-old classical vocabulary, especially as it had been modernized, in his view, by the 19th-century choreographer Marius Petipa. Balanchine's own brand of 20th-century neo-classicism is evident in his reworking of classical technique in this sparkling gem of a ballet. But it is also a work in which he pays overt homage to Petipa by quoting directly from that choreographer's 1898 ballet, "Raymonda," set to Glazounov's music.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; From Italy to Balanchine, via Petipa
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York City Ballet's performance on Saturday afternoon of George Balanchine's "Harlequinade," one of the major revivals of the Balanchine Celebration, may well prove to be one of the happiest and best-danced performances in the festival. nytimes_articles.headline: A Recital and a Debut Merge, to a Degree
nytimes_articles.abstract: Christopher Creaghan, an organist from Canada studying at the Manhattan School, was faced with a degree-requirement recital and a New York debut wrapped into one on Wednesday night at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola. He handled the experience with poise. Mr. Creaghan's program stretched as wide as it knew how over the repertory, often favoring excerpts from a variety of pieces rather than concentrated doses of one or two styles. While some recitals serve particular musical needs, this one was clearly designed to show what one organist could do.   The first half was principally Baroque, offering, among pieces by Sweelinck and Grigny, Bach's C-major Trio Sonata: chaste and cheerful outer movements, an austere Largo in between. The second half tended toward bigger, later works and ended with Messiaen's familiar "Nativite du Seigneur," in which Mr. Creaghan nicely exploited the size of this church and the power of its organ.

nytimes_articles.headline: Limits Seen On Human Existence
nytimes_articles.abstract: IS it possible, using statistics alone, to predict how long space exploration, the Catholic Church, the Miss America contest, the human race or the universe as a whole will continue to exist? A Princeton University astrophysicist has concluded that these and many other predictions are not only possible, but can be made with 95 percent reliability.   As he described his hypothesis in the current issue of the British journal Nature, the scientist, Dr. J. Richard Gott 3d, proposed that the longevity of things can be estimated remarkably well from their histories. All that is needed to calculate roughly how long something is likely to last is to assume that there is nothing special about it -- nothing to particularly distinguish it from all the other objects or systems or creatures or intervals of time in its class. Theorists call this assumption the "Copernican principle," referring to the Polish astronomer Copernicus, who concluded that the Earth was not at the center of the solar system (or universe), and therefore did not occupy any "special" place.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Limits of Tame and Wild at the Zoo
nytimes_articles.abstract: Among the big scenes in "Zoo" are the stillbirth of a rhinoceros, the egg-laying of a crocodile, the tooth-cleaning of a gorilla and the hunt for a pit bull who killed some deer. But Frederick Wiseman is not the sort of documentary maker who settles for big scenes. In this, his 25th work, as in his other studies of American institutions, from a hospital to a race track to Central Park, he allows his subject to reveal itself, the mundane along with the sensational.   What that means for tomorrow night's two-hour visit to the Miami Metrozoo are many pictures of fauna on both sides of the bars. The zoo workers are efficient and conscientious, the visiting children are cute and the elephants, chimpanzees, zebras and so forth are easy to look at, even if you think you recognize most of them from other public television programs. But they do not make for steadily enthralling television. The opening 10 minutes of disporting families and showoff animals tests even a Wiseman fan's endurance, and after the sixth or seventh time the zoo train goes by, you might find yourself hoping for a derailment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Animals That Are Peerless Athletes
nytimes_articles.abstract: TO the recreational joggers of the world, champion runners like Carl Lewis and Olga Markova are the anointed children of Zeus, cardiovascular demigods who seem to ignite the air molecules around them as they race.    Yet even the most elite human athlete is thoroughly pathetic compared with nature's other aerobic masters. Take the pronghorn antelope of Wyoming, for example, a goat-sized ungulate that may rank as the greatest athlete alive. Its maximum speed of 60 miles per hour is second only to the cheetah's top pace of 70 m.p.h. But while the cheetah can sprint for just a few seconds before practically collapsing, the pronghorn can maintain its freeway stride for an hour.

nytimes_articles.abstract: The map of the American West in the first big year of the Oregon Trail showed a sea of open space, and carried warnings about the people who were living on much of it. The Pawnee, Cheyenne, Arapaho, Sioux, Shoshone, Crow, Nez Perce, Ute, Spokane, Cayuse, Chinook, Umpqua -- these tribes were as prominent as any landmark on the migrants' guide of 1843.   Moving west along the old Oregon Trail today, a traveler who wanders off the interstate can still find the American Indian bands that both sustained and threatened the wagon trains. The people live inside straight lines on the map, nations within a nation. They are mostly off the road and out of sight.

nytimes_articles.abstract: McNeil Robinson is one of increasingly few organists who maintain the art of improvisation. Last Tuesday night at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, at a moment's notice, Mr. Robinson conjured up a "symphony in four movements" based on themes submitted by Ned Rorem. Each movement found an effective dramatic shape, expertly deploying Mr. Rorem's fluid and engaging material. Especially impressive was the second movement, an Andante, in which a lilting melody stretched out to fill a space of considerable breadth.   The remainder of the program was taken up by a broad selection of works from different eras: Marcel Dupre's "Sept Pieces," three anonymous 17th-century pieces and Beavarlet-Charpentier's Fugue in A Minor, Bach's Prelude and Fugue in D (B.W.V. 532) and Franck's Choral No. 2. nytimes_articles.headline: Lighten Up on Ukraine
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Since declaring its intention to give up its nuclear weapons almost two years ago, Ukraine has been building up a huge army and hedging its nuclear bets. Ukraine began temporizing only a month after its initial bold declaration, when conspirators in Moscow staged their coup and sent Soviet ground forces to Kiev with an ultimatum: Comply with the new regime or the army moves in. To back up the threat, helicopters reconnoitered the city while special forces trained to seize public buildings took up positions on the outskirts.

For Ukrainians, the incident drove home the precariousness of their sovereignty. Despite U.S. cajoling, Ukrainian legislators appear poised to backtrack and postpone joining the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. While they will likely ratify the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, they will surrender no warheads without firm security guarantees, Russian recognition of existing borders and several billion dollars for dismantling their arsenal.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chess
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hypermodernism is old in the annals of military combat but a latecomer to chess. While its strategy of provoking opponents to overreach themselves and then surround and destroy their frailly supported, advanced units did not become a self-conscious approach to the chess openings until the rise of players like Richard Reti, Gyula Breyer and Aron Nimzovich in the 1920's, this had been stock in trade to the Spartan infantry at least as early as the Persian Wars in the Fifth Century B.C.   Its lure in chess is the spirit of adventure that accompanies a bold plan. What if the opponent's thrust becomes a juggernaut? You are crushed. But what satisfaction there is in undermining the enemy outposts and pouring through the gaps to victory. nytimes_articles.headline: Mr. Colon, Call Home

It is the Council's fundamental job, after all, to give communities a voice in City Hall. A Council member can, for the term ending this year only, live anywhere in the city; because of redistricting in 1991, a court temporarily lifted the residency requirement. If Mr. Colon is found to have violated a law, the Council would have several options, from reprimanding him to expelling him. So far, Speaker Peter Vallone, who firmly controls the Council, has sent mixed signals. Every elected official, he said, "has the moral and legal obligation to live and to serve in the district he or she represents." nytimes_articles.abstract: Using the early morning light to help her fading vision, Michline Reynaers sat recently in a sunny corner of the Hotel Tirol here, knitting socks for a grandchild.   "Everyone in town talked about how well he played the piano," the 72-year-old hotel keeper recalled, speaking in German of the courteous, mustachioed visitor who patronized her restaurant in 1959. "I was introduced to him as Mr. Mengele."

nytimes_articles.headline: Cyclist Hit Twice and Dragged By Drunken Driver, Police Say
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 29-year-old man was knocked off his bicycle by a drunken driver in upper Manhattan on Sunday night, and as he limped to his feet, he was struck a second time by the same car and dragged for eight blocks, the police and witnesses said.   The man, Christopher Donohue, a school custodian, was in critical but stable condition at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center last night. He suffered internal injuries and third-degree friction burns to his face and body, and he lost his left ear, his doctor, M. Kamel Abouzahr, said last night.

nytimes_articles.headline: Koreas: Menace, Uncertainty and a Ray of Hope
nytimes_articles.abstract: - The crisis that looms over the Korean Peninsula - the worst since the armistice was signed nearly 40 years ago - might be quickly resolved were the United Nations not so bogged down in Cambodia and ex-Yugoslavia. The Security Council and political leaders in America and Europe have had little time to study reports of large troop movements in North Korea, where the self-styled Great Leader, Kim Il Sung, 81, faces increasing opposition to his efforts to ensure that his son, Kim Jong Il, 51, will assume power when the elder man departs.

nytimes_articles.abstract: NEW YORK CITY  A ZONING PLAN FOR LINCOLN CENTER   The Planning Department will propose zoning changes that would put new restrictions on commercial development and building heights in the area around Lincoln Center. nytimes_articles.abstract: Walter Stewart, a single-minded investigator of scientific misconduct who believes that his work was improperly halted by the National Institutes of Health, has gone on a hunger strike in protest.    Hunger strikes are rare in science, and few Government employees have embraced the risky tactic. Today was the 21st day of his fast, in which he is taking only water, and Mr. Stewart said in a telephone interview, "I'm getting weak."

nytimes_articles.headline: A Few Players Missing
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of pro league commitments, several top American players will be missing when the United States plays Brazil in the first match of the U.S. Cup '93 on Sunday at New Haven. nytimes_articles.headline: Evidence for Planet X Evaporates in Spotlight of New Research
nytimes_articles.abstract: ASTRONOMERS can quit looking for the elusive "Planet X" because it is not there, a new study of solar system measurements has concluded.   For a half century stargazers have hunted for Planet X, the solar system's hypothetical 10th planet. Its existence was inferred from what appeared to be irregularities in the orbital motions of several known planets. But a new study of the outer planets indicates that the long chase, based on presumed wobbles in the orbits of Uranus and Neptune caused by a planet, was based on erroneous observations and calculations.

nytimes_articles.headline: All Jordan, All Even: Chicago Takes Game 4
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was spectacular, but from Michael Jordan, the spectacular is never unexpected. Jordan was due for a performance like this, a brilliant 54-point barrage that lifted the Chicago Bulls, deflated the Knicks and dramatically changed the atmosphere of a series that New York no longer controls.   Carrying his team with a remarkable long-range shooting exhibition, Jordan led the Bulls to a series-tying 105-95 victory this afternoon at Chicago Stadium in Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals. The four-of-seven-game series is tied, 2-2, heading into a crucial Game 5 confrontation Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON CONSIDERS TAX ON HOSPITALS
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton is seriously considering a new tax on hospitals to help finance medical care for people who currently have no health insurance, Administration officials said today.   The officials said the proposal would be high on the agenda when Mr. Clinton meets this week with his advisers to review the design of his plan to guarantee health care for all Americans.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rabin Shuffles His Cabinet But Critics Aren't Appeased
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a Cabinet shuffle over the weekend, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin managed to put the most serious political crisis of his year-old Government behind him.    But today he still had to contend with criticism of his leadership and the possible implications of his leadership style for the Middle East peace talks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Make Health Reform Work. Draft Doctors.
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The national debate on health care reform has highlighted a fundamental flaw in our medical system -- the lack of doctors, even for those who have insurance, in rural and inner-city areas. There is only one practical way to deliver medical care to the tens of millions of Americans who lack it: mandatory public service by physicians.

At the end of 1992, an estimated 3,700 non-specialist physicians were needed in medically underserved areas. Although many physicians provide care to the needy at a reduced fee or no charge, volunteer efforts, splendid as they are, will never reach all Americans isolated by poverty, geography or residence in inadequate nursing homes, prisons or mental institutions. While these citizens receive care for serious illnesses requiring hospitalization, they remain deprived of basic health care.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nicklaus's Travel Plans
nytimes_articles.abstract: JACK NICKLAUS says his performance in this week's Memorial Tournament will help determine whether he plays in the British Open.   Nicklaus has played in every British Open since turning pro in 1962, and he has won three. But he missed the cut in the championship last year, and he finished 44th and 63d in the two previous years. This year's British Open is July 15-18 at the Royal St. George course in England.

nytimes_articles.headline: Insects Castes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Insects may have developed a social class system at least 95 million years earlier than had been thought, say scientists who stumbled on some fossilized termite nests in Arizona.   The three nests, indications of social behavior and cooperative building, were found in a rock formation that is 220 million years old, said Stephen Hasiotis, a doctoral candidate in paleontology at the University of Colorado in Boulder.

nytimes_articles.headline: To the Spider Woman, Broadway Is Home
nytimes_articles.abstract: Chita Rivera (Dolores Conchita Figueroa del Rivero, to be more precise) is impatient with questions about the Tony Awards on Sunday. She actually rolls her eyes and sighs when asked about whether she thinks she'll win the honors for best actress in a musical, for her title role in "Kiss of the Spider Woman."    "You delude yourself," she said on a recent afternoon at the Broadhurst Theater, in a cozy dressing room overstocked with long-stemmed red roses. "You keep telling yourself it doesn't matter, that whoever wins, that'll be just fine. Then you get there. And? It's war! If you lose, that walk out of the theater is the longest you'll ever take."

nytimes_articles.headline: Brooks Takes a Walk As Devils Jog in Place
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a disagreement with New Jersey's management over the direction the team ought to take, Herb Brooks resigned as coach yesterday after fulfilling one season of the three-year contract he was given last June 5 to "take the Devils to the next level."   Brooks, whose team (40-37-7) tied the Islanders for third place in the Patrick Division but was eliminated in five games by Pittsburgh in the first round of the playoffs, wanted the Devils to, in effect, take a step backward before going forward. The 55-year-old coach viewed youth and speed as the main ingredients for building success. Management felt the players on the team were good enough to become Stanley Cup contenders.

nytimes_articles.headline: Purity, Pederasty And a Fallen Heroine
nytimes_articles.abstract: On the morning of April 2, in the courthouse of the small northern California mining town of Jamestown, a preliminary hearing was under way on charges against Daniel Driver for allegedly molesting several young boys. During the proceedings, the mother of one of the boys, Ellie Nesler, thought she detected Mr. Driver smirking. So she went and got a gun, walked back into court and stopped the smirks forever. Now charged with murder, Ellie Nesler, cast by the law as a killer, has made herself available for the role of cultural heroine.   Ellie Nesler took us at our word. Believing that Mr. Driver was a pederast, she did what society wants done to pederasts: she plugged him five times, stopping perversion dead in its tracks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yanks and Perez Get A Picnic on the Grass
nytimes_articles.abstract: Melido Perez is not used to this feeling. He knows what it's like to pitch with no runs in his favor. He knows what it's like to pitch out of a hole. But pitching with a lead -- a big lead -- is a new thing for him.   Perez did not expect the Yankees to provide him with eight runs yesterday afternoon at the Stadium. Usually, he's lucky to get three. And with Bernie Williams, Don Mattingly and Danny Tartabull on the disabled list, the Yankee offense should be suffering, not racking up the hits.

pages.title: Dobrinja mortar attack
pages.description: 1993 massacre of Bosnian civilians in Sarajevo
pages.abstract: The Dobrinja mortar attack was a massacre which occurred at 10:20 a.m. on 1 June 1993, in Dobrinja, a suburb west of Sarajevo in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Two mortar rounds were fired from Serb-held positions, hitting a football pitch where youths put on an impromptu game on the first day of the Muslim holiday Kurban Bajram. Approximately 200 people were in attendance to watch the game. The United Nations placed the official death toll stemming from the mortar attack at 13, with 133 wounded. At the time it was the deadliest event involving civilians since the imposition of sanctions against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia by the United Nations one year prior.

pages.title: Dobrinja
pages.description: Neighborhood in Sarajevo Canton, Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bosnia and Herzegovina
pages.abstract: Dobrinja is a neighbourhood in the western outskirts of Sarajevo, part of the municipality of Novi Grad. It is estimated to have a population of 25,063 inhabitants. Its name comes from the short river Dobrinja that flows through it. It is today organised in four local communities. Dobrinja lies just north of Sarajevo International Airport.

pages.title: Sarajevo

The Sarajevo metropolitan area including Sarajevo Canton, East Sarajevo and nearby municipalities is home to 555,210 inhabitants. Located within the greater Sarajevo valley of Bosnia, it is surrounded by the Dinaric Alps and situated along the Miljacka River in the heart of the Balkans, a region of Southern Europe.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton's Order on M.I.A. Data a Small Shift
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's announcement on Monday that he had ordered the declassification of all but a tiny fraction of military documents on Americans who did not return from the war in Southeast Asia represents only a small change from Bush Administration policy.    In July, President Bush ordered the declassification of 200,000 pages of State Department papers and 2,600 pages of Central Intelligence Agency materials related to the 2,260 American servicemen listed as unaccounted for in the Vietnam War, Administration officials said today. nytimes_articles.headline: Too Many Musicians? An Overhaul at Juilliard -- A special report.; A New Juilliard for a More Challenging Era
nytimes_articles.abstract: The sun was beating strongly on the plaza in front of the Juilliard School on a recent weekday, but the real heat was coming from another source. Before an audience of students sprawled on the white stone or crowded around a buffet table set up for the school's year-end picnic, Eugene Park was going through an ear-splitting, high-voltage rendition of a Hungarian czardas by Vittorio Monti.   This was a crowd that knew its Monti and liked what it was hearing. Mr. Park, a first-year student whose face was obscured by long hair, rocked back and forth on his heels in the slower sections, building anticipation, then let it rip in the fast passages, bow hairs snapping as he punished the strings of his electric violin. It was Paganini with a few dashes of Pete Townshend thrown in for extra attitude. The students clapped and whistled, grateful perhaps for diversion from the week's main focus: solo performances before a faculty jury to determine their final grades. The Advent of Change    It was a scene at odds with the traditional picture of Juilliard, the most prestigious conservatory in the United States, and perhaps in the world, one whose graduates account for about 20 percent of the musicians in the Big Five American orchestras (and half of those in the New York Philharmonic).

nytimes_articles.headline: ATTACK ON YELTSIN STEPPED UP BY FOE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi stepped up his attacks on President Boris N. Yeltsin today and called on the Russian Parliament to disband his Government "completely and immediately."   Mr. Rutskoi's new offensive came as Russia's warring political factions head into a major battle over a new constitution, which Mr. Yeltsin will put on the table this weekend at a specially summoned conference. The conference, which opens on Saturday, was expanded today, as Mr. Yeltsin ordered each of the Russian Federation's 88 regions and territories to double their representation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Panthers Expected to Name Neilson Coach
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Florida Panthers scheduled a news conference for today amid speculation they will name the former Rangers coach ROGER NEILSON as their first head coach. nytimes_articles.headline: Stony Brook President Plans to Step Down
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. John H. Marburger, president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, announced today that he would step down and return to teaching, ending a 13-year tenure marked by strains to maintain academic standards as state aid steadily declined.   In announcing his resignation, Dr. Marburger said he would leave his $146,000 position as soon as a successor is found, which he estimated would take up to a year. He pointed out that when he was appointed to the post in 1980 he said he planned to stay for only 10 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: After Jordan Does Damage, Riley Finds Another Target
nytimes_articles.abstract: Disturbed that Michael Jordan has attempted 17 more free throws than Patrick Ewing during their last two games, Pat Riley cried foul today.   Riley's complaints about the officiating provided more intrigue leading up to Game 5 of the Eastern Conference championship, the most critical game of the Knicks' season. nytimes_articles.headline: Guatemalan Who Grabbed Power Is Out
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Guatemalan military forced President Jorge Serrano Elias from office today with the backing of political parties, business executives and some civic groups. Eight days ago, Mr. Serrano seized nearly dictatorial powers with the Army's support.   As Mr. Serrano sat under guard and hundreds of demonstrators chanted at the gates of the National Palace for a civilian government, military commanders worked out a settlement with political leaders and jurists late this afternoon to restore democracy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fernandez Turns Rout Into Rousing Comeback
nytimes_articles.abstract: She was on the run, on the defensive, and, after two sets on the French Open's red clay against Steffi Graf, Jennifer Capriati was on her way home to Florida. nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Admits Big Changes In Budget Plan Are Needed
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton conceded today that he would have to reduce his tax proposals and cut spending more deeply to get his economic program through the Senate, but he held out the hope that his plans to put more money into education and job training would not be gutted in the process.   In a speech here, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that large changes in his budget plan were inevitable and set out five areas that he did not want touched. He asked negotiators to leave intact his goal of reducing the deficit by $500 billion over four years, to approve only those new taxes that affect the rich more than the poor, to keep measures for small business and for the working poor and to retain spending cuts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Personal Health
nytimes_articles.abstract: OF all the diseases that have failed to yield to the war on cancer, one of the most frustrating to researchers, clinicians and patients is ovarian cancer. Despite new treatments that prolong life, in the last three decades there has been little improvement in long-term survival. Early, curable ovarian cancer produces no symptoms, and three-fourths of cases are not diagnosed until the cancer has spread beyond the ovarian capsule.   Once the disease has advanced beyond the ovary, fewer than 10 percent of women are cured. But if it is detected and treated early, 90 percent survive, a fact that has prompted a frantic search for cost-effective ways to screen women for early signs. The death on May 20, 1989, of the 42-year-old comedian Gilda Radner from ovarian cancer produced an outpouring of concern about the disease.

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Connie Chung at the Anchor Desk
nytimes_articles.abstract: So as of last night it is "The CBS Evening News With Dan Rather and Connie Chung." Why the addition of the last three words? nytimes_articles.headline: Shandling's Blend of Fact and Parody
nytimes_articles.abstract: One wall of Garry Shandling's office here is covered with newspaper clippings describing the latest twists and turns in the late-night television game: a little bit of Letterman, a little bit of Leno, some Arsenio Hall and Chevy Chase.   Mr. Shandling could easily have included several recent headlines about another prospective late-night talk-show host: Garry Shandling. Back in April, when NBC was pursuing Mr. Shandling to take over Mr. Letterman's "Late Night" show in the 12:35 A.M. slot, it was all over the newspapers. There still are rumors that CBS will offer him a show to follow David Letterman on that network.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Wishing Won't Do. Regarding "Star Wars Is Dead! Long Live BMDO!" (Opinion, May 22) by Charles Krauthammer:. The Ballistic Missile Defense Organization, successor to the "star wars" program, demonstrates a kind of wishful thinking: Devi

nytimes_articles.headline: Navajos Are Asked to Aid Effort to Contain an Illness
nytimes_articles.abstract: The leader of the country's largest Indian tribe went on tribal radio today to beseech his people in their own language to cooperate with the medical investigators searching for the cause of a mysterious illness that has killed 12 people since March.    Peterson Zah, president of the Navajo Nation, appealed to tribe members to visit one of the six Indian Health Service Hospitals on the vast Navajo Reservation to be checked if they felt any of the illness's symptoms, which include body aches and fever.

nytimes_articles.headline: Paige Retires From Dolphins
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fullback TONY PAIGE, who made a career out of creating holes, left a big one for the Miami Dolphins yesterday. The reliable blocker and pass receiver unexpectedly told Coach DON SHULA that he's retiring. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: LIBYANS CUT SHORT A VISIT TO ISRAEL
nytimes_articles.abstract: Muslim pilgrims from Libya suddenly cut short their visit here today after calling for the overthrow of the "Zionist leadership," the "liberation" of Jerusalem and the establishment of a "democratic" Palestinian state of Arabs and Jews.   Israeli officials, some of whom had hailed the visit as a portent of peace, were surprised and outraged by the remarks, made at a news conference.  The strange collapse of an already strange pilgrimage quickly dampened speculation that the trip might promote ties with Libya after years of unbending hostility.

nytimes_articles.headline: Congress's Twists and Turns Reshape Bill on Energy Tax
nytimes_articles.abstract: Five months ago, seeking to raise billions for President Clinton's economic programs and at the same time promote conservation, the White House proposed a broad tax on most forms of energy.   Then armies of lobbyists beseeched the White House to make the tax fairer, squadrons of Congressmen amended it to make it less onerous, and Mr. Clinton horse-traded some clauses to gain support for his budget.

nytimes_articles.headline: Leader's Edge in Debate Cheers Spain's Socialists
nytimes_articles.abstract: Convinced that another lackluster performance by Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez would doom its chances of victory in general elections on Sunday, the Spanish Socialist Party breathed a sigh of relief today when the final televised debate of the campaign ended.    Handily defeated in the first debate last week, Mr. Gonzalez came out fighting from the first bell this time and, in the opinion of independent commentators and Spanish newspapers, scored a clear victory over his conservative challenger, Jose Maria Aznar.

nytimes_articles.headline: Skeptics and Lobbyists Besiege Student Loan Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's proposal to change the way college students get education loans has bogged down in the face of a banking industry lobbying blitz and criticism of the White House's assumption that the Government can administer loans more efficiently than private lenders.   The Administration maintains that it can save students and the Government billions of dollars a year in interest and other lending costs by replacing "middlemen" like the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, and making the loans itself through the Department of Education. The House appears ready to go along with the plan, but the Senate is sharply divided.

nytimes_articles.headline: A History of Gergenism
nytimes_articles.abstract: Talk about being present at the creation. David R. Gergen helped package the Reagan Administration policies that, according to Bill Clinton, almost wrecked America. It is a measure of Democratic desperation and of Mr. Gergen's popularity inside the Beltway that his appointment is being hailed as a gain for the shell-shocked White House. Maybe Mr. Gergen can help end the press-room follies that have cost Mr. Clinton so dearly.   But this appointment has other meanings as well. It points up a deterioration of political values and an erosion of journalistic standards in the capital. And it suggests that the Arkansas crowd not only came to Washington without experience, but also without a clipping file or a historical memory.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON IDEA USED TO LIMIT WELFARE
nytimes_articles.abstract: States have begun appropriating an idea that President Clinton popularized in the fall campaign, beating him to the punch by issuing their own plans to place two-year limits on welfare benefits.   The actions create a potential dilemma for the Clinton Administration, which must decide whether to approve them on an experimental basis.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Overrated? Overpaid? Not These 3
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT'S easy to pounce on those millionaires who aren't worth their money. Bobby Bonilla has been hitting home runs for the Mets lately but not enough to justify his $6.2 million salary. Jon Koncak of the Atlanta Hawks didn't do much this season for his $2.6 million. Eric Lindros is still an investment in the Philadelphia Flyers' future at more than $3 million.   Overrated and overpaid. It's enough to make some people think that no athlete can possibly be worth that much money.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cambodia: A Vote Worth Defending
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's offensive for the present Government of Cambodia to protest "irregularities" in last week's U.N.-run elections. By most impartial accounts, the voting was conducted fairly. And those doing the protesting have dirty hands; during the campaign preceding the vote their side engaged in assassinations and other forms of political intimidation.   Just 10 days ago it looked as if the 1991 Cambodia peace accords might unravel in a violently disrupted or boycotted election. But in a surprising democratic triumph, more than 90 percent of eligible Cambodians braved death threats to cast their votes in an election that monitors certify as free and fair.

nytimes_articles.headline: O'Connor Reflects on Role In Eye of Moral Tempests
nytimes_articles.abstract: Reflecting on nearly 10 turbulent years at the helm of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he might have gone too far at times in thrusting himself and his church into secular politics -- from his implicit criticism of Geraldine A. Ferraro in 1984 to his loose alliance with Pat Robertson last month.   "Time after time I have to ask myself if the Church would be better off -- certainly, I would be better off -- if when I came here I had just become a silent servant of the people," the Cardinal said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pogorelovka Journal; The Russians Follow Their Hearts, Back to Russia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Three years ago, at the first inkling of a collapse of the Soviet empire, Leonid N. Podolyan and two friends, all Russians living in the remote Central Asian republic of Kyrgyzstan, piled into a car and drove several thousand miles along the bumpy roads of Russia's heartland, looking for a new place to call home.   They found it here in a ramshackle village by the banks of the River Pronya, about 40 miles south of Ryazan, on the territory of a state chicken farm named 60th Anniversary of October, which offered them as good a deal they were likely to get.

nytimes_articles.headline: Game 5 Looks a Lot Like Game 7 for Knicks
nytimes_articles.abstract: All the plans, the work, the investments are at stake tonight. More than one series. More than one basketball season. Reputations are on the line. Futures. Dreams.   In two decades, the Knicks have not played a game as important as the one they will play tonight against Chicago at Madison Square Garden. It is no overreaction to say they must win Game 5 of the Eastern Conference finals. It is no attempt to overstate the night merely to heighten the pressure on the Knicks. Pat Riley knows his team has no room for missteps. His players know it. Stan Jaffe and Dave Checketts and Ernie Grunfeld of the front office know it, too.

nytimes_articles.headline: Once-Limping Bulls Steeled to March East
nytimes_articles.abstract: Having reduced the worst of what Madison Square Garden can offer to the analytical intensity of a film session, and having replaced their angry rhetoric with consecutive victories, the Chicago Bulls prepared today to return to face the Knicks in Game 5 of the Eastern Conference final. Chicago is in far better condition than the team that left New York last week.   The Bulls have had time to regroup and heal. They have gained the success, and the perspective, to transform their responses to questions about officiating from confrontational to complimentary.

nytimes_articles.headline: GERMANY PRESSED TO CURB VIOLENCE
nytimes_articles.abstract: After the second fatal firebombing of a house occupied by Turks in six months, the German Government is under renewed pressure to crack down on far-rightist and neo-Nazi activity.   Five girls and women of Turkish origin, ranging in age from 4 to 27, died on Saturday in a firebombing in the western town of Solingen. Three Turks died in a similar attack in Molln on Nov. 23.

nytimes_articles.headline: Suns Win Behind Barkley, Majerle
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dan Majerle camped out 26-feet from the basket tonight. His teammate Charles Barkley was quite willing to be a one-man team, but Majerle gave the Phoenix Suns a second option for once. The release on Majerle's shot was so picturesque this evening, it should have been commissioned to a local artist.   His eight 3-point shots broke a National Basketball Association playoff record, and the only two he missed touched inside the rim before curling out. In the process, Majerle proved that the Phoenix Suns are superior as a tag team, that he and Barkley could run a treadmill all day long and that his teeth do not chatter with his team on a ledge.

nytimes_articles.headline: 3 Youths Go on Trial in Shooting Death of Brooklyn Principal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nearly six months after a popular school principal was shot and killed while walking through a Brooklyn housing project, three teen-agers went on trial for murder yesterday, accused of taking part in a running gun battle in which the victim was caught.   In a case that drew national attention to the lethally random perils in neighborhoods riddled with guns and drugs, jury selection began in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn for the defendants -- one of whose bullets the authorities say tore into the chest of Patrick Daly, the 48-year-old longtime principal of Public School 15.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wreaking Havoc -- and Selling Sneaks
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pro basketball is one part aerial ballet and one part controlled brutality. Charles Barkley, the bruising, blunt-talking forward for the Phoenix Suns and the league's most valuable player, is less an aerialist than a skilled practitioner of force. He has chased referees from the stadium and verbally accosted fans, while intimidating opposing players. Mr. Barkley, or at least the image he tries to project, stands at great odds with the notion that athletes ought to be paragons of virtue and temperateness to inspire the nation's youth.   Thus it's an ingenious irony that Nike sporting goods is starring Sir Charles in a television commercial about role models. Staring into the camera, Mr. Barkley says: "I am not a role model. I am not paid to be a role model. I am paid to wreak havoc on the basketball court." Mr. Barkley points out that "parents should be role models" and notes that his ability to dunk a basketball does not make him fit to raise America's children.

nytimes_articles.headline: MORTAR FIRE KILLS 12 AT SOCCER GAME IN BOSNIAN CAPITAL
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mortar shells exploded today amid a neighborhood soccer tournament, killing at least a dozen people and wounding 80 in the worst single incident in a year in the bombardment of the city by Bosnian Serb forces.   Shrapnel-peppered cars, drying pools of blood, a few shreds of blood-soaked clothing and a worn-out soccer ball were all that remained afterward in the parking lot where about 100 players and spectators had gathered for the game.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Sex and the Talk Shows: Con and Pro
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tonight's somewhat scattershot "48 Hours" tour of the talk-show universe settles down briefly for a report by Dan Rather on Phil Donahue's troubles with Richard Neill, a Fort Worth dentist. Dr. Neill is trying to extract shows like "Donahue" from afternoon television because they are infected with sexual display and bizarre confessionals.   Mr. Donahue's main defense, which he has used more than once in his 25 years on television, is that he is competing with like-minded or mindless programs for big audiences. He says, "You cannot televise the front page of The Wall Street Journal and survive." And he protests that his critics never give him credit for his programs about racism, Bosnia and other unsexy subjects.

nytimes_articles.headline: 3,000 Subway Riders, Cards in Hand, Test New Fare System
nytimes_articles.abstract: With six months to go before computer-coded cards start replacing subway tokens, the Transit Authority began its first large-scale test of the automated fare-collection system yesterday, handing out 3,000 sample cards to regular subway riders.   The seven-week experiment will test the cards and the computerized turnstiles that use them, and will allow officials to focus more intently on how passengers take to the new method of entering the subway. Results of the test, transit officials say, will help them prepare instructions on how to use the card when it is introduced later this year.

nytimes_articles.headline: 5 Cubans In Search of a Club
nytimes_articles.abstract: Last year, Rene Arocha became the first national-team defector in three decades of Cuban baseball, and now he is a starting pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals.   This year, five more Cuban defectors have arrived in the United States to chase the same intoxicating dream -- and they have the advantage of knowing it's possible. Call it the Arocha Connection.

nytimes_articles.headline: METROPOLITAN GOLF REPORT
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nynex Commemorative    Bob Charles of New Zealand, the leading career money winner on the Senior PGA Tour and arguably the best left-handed golfer, was the honoree in last night's dinner at Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y., where the 14th edition of the tournament will be staged this week.   Charles captured the Commemorative in 1988 and 1989. This is the 30th anniversary of his victory in the 1963 British Open, where he beat Phil Rodgers in a playoff at Royal Lytham. Charles won the Canadian Open 25 years ago; 20 years ago, he captured the New Zealand Open, the Scandinavian Open and the South African Open.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cyclist Shot to Death in Brooklyn's Prospect Park
nytimes_articles.abstract: A man riding his new mountain bike through Brooklyn's Prospect Park was shot three times in the back and killed yesterday afternoon when he attempted to flee from robbers who wanted to steal the bike, the police said.   The killing, on a sunlit afternoon that brought scores of people to the park, occurred on a winding dirt road, just yards away from joggers and ball fields, near one of the park's jewels, Swan Lake.

nytimes_articles.headline: Belgrade Riots Follow President's Ouster
nytimes_articles.abstract: Thousands of demonstrators clashed with riot police in front of the Parliament building in downtown Belgrade Tuesday night in the most serious anti-Government demonstration here in two years.    A score of demonstrators were injured as the crowd stormed the Parliament, smashing windows and chanting "Justice!" and "Rise up, Belgrade!" They threw rocks at the police, who charged them with truncheons under a torrent of tear gas. At least three members of the security forces were badly injured, Belgrade television said. The police said 18 demonstrators were injured, according to the Associated Press.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Britain and the United States may have resolved their political differences long ago, but when it comes to music, traces of national chauvinism endure.   Take the squabble now being conducted in the letters column of The Times of London by DENNIS MARKS, general director-designate of the English National Opera, on one side, and two respected members of the British music establishment, Dame JANET BAKER, the mezzo-soprano, and RICHARD FISHER, general administrator of the Royal Philharmonic Society, on the other.

nytimes_articles.headline: PEN Fights Censoring Of Gay Writers
nytimes_articles.abstract: PEN American Center, the American division of the international writers' association, has formed a committee to combat what it described as censorship of gay and lesbian writing and to work to insure that readers have access to such writing.   The organization said the committee "will expose and oppose" threats to the First Amendment from actions like the banning of gay books by school libraries. The committee's formation is to be formally announced this morning.

nytimes_articles.headline: Death Row, U.S.A.
nytimes_articles.abstract: At 12:01 A.M. tomorrow, Texas, which makes a habit of capital punishment, plans to execute Gary Graham, a black, for a murder committed a dozen years ago, when he was 17 years old. Elsewhere in the West, he would not be put to death.   President Clinton supports the death penalty. But his record in his first two-year term as Governor of Arkansas, in which he reduced the life sentences of 38 murderers, suggests he may have held a different view.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Pin This Loss On Young
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anthony Young sat transfixed as the television screen inside the Mets' clubhouse flashed one terrible sequence after another. There was a single to left field and then a single barely inside the bag at third. There was a double-play grounder that became a single because a hit-and-run play was on. There was a double to the ivy wall in left-center and a two-run single to right.   Young, cursing occasionally at no one in particular, kept staring at the screen.

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Hunting for the Musical Thread
nytimes_articles.abstract: There was a bit of a challenge about the seventh annual Bang on a Can Festival, which came to an end at the Kitchen on Sunday night after 10 concerts, 82 compositions and about 22 hours of music. The challenge was to find something coherent in the festival's deliberate eclecticism, some sense of a governing taste or theme, some characteristics of whatever style is now dominant in what was once called the downtown music scene. As in other seasons, the directors of the festival -- David Lang, Michael Gordon and Julia Wolfe -- have done everything possible to minimize the sense of a governing voice or taste.   I found the selections weaker than they were last year but the variety no less fascinating. The concerts included, for example, a remarkable Chinese shadow play by the Yueh Lung Shadow Theater in which a mythic tale of a prince battling dragons was told with delicate miniature images projected on a screen. The ancient art form was accompanied by music by Bun-Ching Lam that had echoes of the traditional, in the timbres of the Chinese pipa, along with an almost edgy contemporary sensibility.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fittipaldi Didn't Know It Was a Milk Run
nytimes_articles.abstract: EMERSON FITTIPALDI, who saluted his Indianapolis 500 victory Sunday with an unconventional drink of orange juice, apologized yesterday for passing up a bottle of milk, a 60-year tradition in Victory Lane.   He said the posted prize of $5,500 from the American Dairy Association of Indiana would go instead to the Championship Auto Racing Auxiliary, a women's group that supports various charities.

nytimes_articles.headline: Graduates and Voters
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I was very pleased that Congress has approved the motor voter bill (front page, May 12), which will make voter registration procedures more convenient. I have another suggestion -- require high schools across the country that receive any Federal funds to provide students with voter registration forms on graduation day.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hostos Commencement
nytimes_articles.abstract: Cesar A. Perales, deputy mayor of New York City for Health and Human Services, addressed the 455 graduates at the 22d commencement exercises of Eugenio Maria de Hostos Community College of the City University of New York. In a ceremony presided over by the college's president, Isaura Santiago, the students marched up the aisles of the concert hall at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts. Hostos Community College is the first of the City University of New York colleges to be deliberately placed in an economically depressed community, the South Bronx. It is devoted to bilingual education and serves more than 5,000 students, 75 percent of whom come from Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic and Central and South America.

nytimes_articles.headline: Slaney Is Off and Convalescing
nytimes_articles.abstract: MARY SLANEY has undergone surgery on her left heel, ending her track season before it started. Slaney, who hopes to run some road races by the end of the summer, will miss the USA Mobil Outdoor Track and Field Championships, which will be held June 15-19 in Eugene, Ore. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Court Counts the Ways Guns Can Be Used
nytimes_articles.abstract: There was a war of words at the Supreme Court today, but it wasn't over any technical, obscure, polysyllabic legal term. It was over the word "use."   A Federal law subjects anyone who uses a firearm in connection with a drug offense to a mandatory prison sentence of up to 30 years, depending on the type of gun. But suppose the gun is used not as an instrument of violence, not to injure or threaten, but as an object to barter: in this case, one machine gun for two ounces of cocaine. Is that the kind of use that qualifies for the mandatory sentence?

nytimes_articles.headline: Lawyer Takes Plea Deal In Real-Estate Schemes
nytimes_articles.abstract: As angry clients waited to tell their stories, a disbarred lawyer surprised Federal prosecutors at a bail hearing today and pleaded guilty to defrauding investors of more than $3 million with bogus real-estate projects.   The defendant, Alan David Harris of Roslyn Harbor and Brentwood, Calif., pleaded guilty to 25 counts of mail and wire fraud and faces up to 125 years in prison and fines of up to $6.25 million. He was also ordered to make restitution and a full accounting of how he spent the stolen money.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; The Disabled Come Out Fighting
nytimes_articles.abstract: No Pity  People With Disabilities Forging a New Civil Rights Movement  By Joseph P. Shapiro  372 pages. Times Books. $25.    It took a President with polio (Franklin D. Roosevelt, who couldn't walk on his own) and the severely injured veterans of World War II, Korea and Vietnam to make Americans aware that being disabled wasn't something to hide and be ashamed of. Then it took demonstrations and lobbying to force the Federal Government to recognize that people with disabilities ought to be included under the big umbrella of civil rights.

nytimes_articles.headline: SENATE DEMOCRATS URGE WITHDRAWAL OF RIGHTS NOMINEE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senior White House officials and Democratic senators said today that President Clinton's nomination of Lani Guinier to be the Justice Department's civil rights chief would have to be withdrawn because of mounting opposition in the Senate and the Administration's attempt to sprint to the political center.   The nomination has been intensely criticized for articles Ms. Guinier wrote on the Voting Rights Act that her critics say make her a proponent of extreme race-based proposals.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Week Well Marred
nytimes_articles.abstract: - If a week is a long time in politics, war and commerce, it can be an eternity in soccer, where all three factors come into play.

nytimes_articles.headline: Foes of Execution Contest a Texas Case
nytimes_articles.abstract: If the State of Texas has its way, Gary Graham will be executed before dawn on Thursday for the killing of Bobby Lambert in a robbery 12 years ago. But no physical evidence links Mr. Graham to the crime, and opponents of the death penalty have seized on his case as emblematic of serious flaws in the system of capital punishment here.   Mr. Graham, 29, was convicted in 1981 on the strength of testimony from a single witness, who was in her car roughly 40 feet from where Mr. Lambert was shot and briefly saw his killer. Since the trial, six other witnesses and five alibi witnesses have sworn that Mr. Graham was not the assailant, but Texas law prohibits the presentation of new evidence after 30 days after conviction.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wilkens Chosen to Coach Hawks
nytimes_articles.abstract: LENNY WILKENS, who spent the past seven seasons with the Cleveland Cavaliers and is closing in on RED AUERBACH's record for most National Basketball Association victories, was named coach of the Atlanta Hawks yesterday.   In becoming the seventh coach in Atlanta Hawks history, Wilkens inherits a team that has not gotten past the first round of the playoffs the past four years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yankee Pitching Staff Picked Apart by Tribe
nytimes_articles.abstract: It started with Mike Witt, who had poor location and no control. It ended with Rich Monteleone, who made a healthy contribution to what is now a 5.56 earned run average by the Yankee bullpen.   There was nothing but ugliness in between.

nytimes_articles.headline: Coney Island Wonder Wheel Won't Rest on Golden Arches
nytimes_articles.abstract: Worried that the Cyclone and the Parachute Jump would be joined by the "McWheel" in a new Coney Island trinity, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has rejected a plan to install 17-foot-wide, neon golden arches on the Wonder Wheel.   Under the plan, the owners of the Wonder Wheel had offered free advertising space to McDonald's, which has two restaurants nearby. But the landmarks panel feared the company's well-known logo would eclipse the 150-foot-high, 200-ton structure.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Pop Life
nytimes_articles.abstract: Springsteen for Charity   Bruce Springsteen is coming home to New Jersey and next door to New York for his only two concerts in the United States this year. The shows, both charity events, are to be on June 24 at Brendan Byrne Arena at the Meadowlands and on June 26 at Madison Square Garden.   The first concert is to benefit three hunger-related organizations: the Community Food Bank of New Jersey, World Hunger Year, and the Food and Hunger Hotline. Proceeds from the June 26 performance are to go to the Kristen Ann Carr Fund, which was created earlier this year in memory of the daughter of Mr. Springsteen's co-manager, Barbara Carr, and Dave Marsh, a writer. The fund will be used to establish a research fellowship dedicated to the study and prevention of sarcoma, a form of cancer.

nytimes_articles.headline: Organ Shortage Leads to Nontraditional Transplants, and Ethical Concerns
nytimes_articles.abstract: Faced with a severe shortage of organs for transplant, some doctors are quietly turning to patients who would not ordinarily be considered suitable donors.   Traditionally, before a patient can qualify as a donor it must be declared that there is no brain function. If such a patient is put on a ventilator, the organs can be kept healthy and perfused with blood until they are needed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Maybe the Lakers: Magic Wants a Team to Coach and Own
nytimes_articles.abstract: Magic Johnson is more likely to someday coach the Los Angeles Lakers than the Los Angeles Clippers.   Johnson, the former Lakers All-Star, said he will not accept any coaching job unless he can buy a small percentage of the team, and the Lakers' owner is more willing to sell to him than the Clippers' owner.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; A TV Host as a TV Host. Familiar?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Starting new seasons tonight, two Home Box Office comedy series are being presented back to back. Expanded beyond their normal 30 minutes, "The Larry Sanders Show" runs from 10 to 10:45 and "Dream On" from 10:45 to 11:45. If you can catch only one, make it "Larry Sanders."    Like "Seinfeld," in which the real stand-up comic Jerry Seinfeld plays a fictional stand-up comic named Jerry Seinfeld, "Larry Sanders" hovers tantalizingly between reality and fiction. Larry, the talk-show host, is played by Garry Shandling, once a frequent guest host for Johnny Carson and now, with the late-night scene churning furiously, being mentioned as a candidate for his own show, possibly after the new David Letterman package on CBS.

nytimes_articles.headline: Volunteer at White House Said to Have Received Fee
nytimes_articles.abstract: A volunteer brought in to the White House travel office to help with charters when career employees were dismissed two weeks ago received a $1,400 commission for the first flight she arranged, then returned the fee when questions were asked about it, The Washington Post reported in Wednesday's issue.   The White House did not have a response late tonight when asked about The Post's account. The Post said George Stephanopolous, a senior adviser at the White House, had replied when asked about the commission: "It was a mistake. She did not realize the funds were going to her firm."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Talk of Hollywood; Women Criticizing Women's Film Roles
nytimes_articles.abstract: There are more female executives and producers in the movies than ever before. That's the good news. The bad news is that there are more films that depict women as chattel ("Indecent Proposal" and "Honeymoon in Vegas") to be purchased by Robert Redford and James Caan, or airheads ("Sliver") who move into a weird New York apartment building owned by William Baldwin, or appendages ("A Few Good Men") who make Tom Cruise, as a Navy officer, look smart.   Why are there so many films made that portray women in embarrassing ways when women are becoming more powerful in Hollywood? What are the responsibilities of female executives, producers and agents?

nytimes_articles.headline: College Overstepped In Removing Jeffries
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   A Federal jury's ruling in favor of Prof. Leonard Jeffries of City College in New York (front page, May 12) has provoked much misguided criticism.

nytimes_articles.headline: Finally, Italy Revolts
nytimes_articles.abstract:
While our judges continue to investigate widespread governmental corruption, uncovering a vast network of illegal political financing and private kickbacks, we Italians hear a lot of talk about a revolution.

The latest scene in this revolution was an alley behind the Uffizi Gallery in Florence where a car bomb explosion announced that terrorists, probably the Mafia, had declared war on civil society.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cuomo to Get Racing Report
nytimes_articles.abstract: The final report of an advisory panel looking for ways to revive the state's beleaguered horse racing industry is expected to be delivered to Gov. Mario Cuomo today.    According to a person familiar with the Governor's Advisory Commission on Racing in the 21st Century, the report recommends immediate reductions in the state's takeout from wagers and in the state's share of breakage, or the way bets are rounded off for bookkeeping purposes. Lower withholding taxes are also recommended for certain winning bets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Man Admits to Robberies Using a Syringe
nytimes_articles.abstract: A homeless man yesterday admitted that he robbed several Upper East Side antique stores, armed with an unusual weapon: a syringe that he said was filled with blood tainted with H.I.V.   In State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Ross Gottfried, 40 years old, pleaded guilty to five felony counts of robbery. He acknowledged that from April 22 to May 3, he robbed stores at 230 East 80th Street, 1135 Madison Avenue, 957 Madison Avenue, 980 Lexington Avenue and 219 East 60th Street.

nytimes_articles.headline: School Hallways as Gantlets of Sexual Taunts
nytimes_articles.abstract: The hallways of America's high schools and junior high schools -- the highways and byways between classrooms, locker rooms and the outside world -- are daunting, sexually charged terrain where most girls and many boys can routinely expect to be grabbed, poked, pinched or put down in explicitly sexual ways.   This picture emerges from a new survey by the poll taker Louis Harris & Associates for the American Association of University Women Educational Foundation. It is the first study that tries to quantify both what teen-agers do to one another and how they react when it happens.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Encourages Reporting Of Adverse Medical Reactions
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration today announced a program to encourage nurses, doctors, dentists and pharmacists to report dangerous side effects from drugs and medical devices.   Until now, manufacturers have been chiefly responsible for reporting dangerous and unexpected effects of drugs and devices they sell. But agency officials say that in large part because medical professionals have not been encouraged to report adverse reactions only 1 in 10 or perhaps even 1 in 100 of those caused by drugs became known. And for medical devices like breast implants, they say, the rate of reporting has been even lower.

nytimes_articles.headline: Devils Renew an Unwanted and Unwelcome Ritual
nytimes_articles.abstract: Looking for a coach is becoming an annual ritual for Lou Lamoriello, the president and general manager of the Devils. He was working toward that end again yesterday, seeking a replacement for Herb Brooks, who resigned on Monday.   "I'm looking at all the people available and I'm trying to narrow down the list," Lamoriello said by telephone from his office in the New Jersey Meadowlands. "I am not ruling out the possibility of hiring someone from within."

nytimes_articles.headline: 3-Year-Old Bronx Girl Wounded by Bullet
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Jasmine Zapata felt a sting on her arm as she played in front of her Bronx home yesterday, she told her nanny, "A ball hit me."   It was not a ball, but a bullet, that struck the 3-year-old girl just after 2 P.M. on the sidewalk outside her family's home at 2757 Sedgwick Avenue in Kingsbridge.
